segments.text: Leora was only four years old when she first understood what it meant to die, or at least she thought so.
The black phone, which lay on the reception desk at the entrance to the pink house, rang, and she saw Lucy pick up the receiver, bring it to her ear, and say, hello.
She was sprawled on the carpet next to the reception desk, beside the armchair in the small foyer, which in different circumstances and in a different size would be called a lobby.
Kim lay beside her, letting her tickle and pet him, emitting purrs of contentment.
She heard Lucy talking pleasantly with someone on the other end of the line and then returning the phone to its place.
Run to Ilishka and tell her to come because the aunt from Haifa will call again in 10 minutes.
Lucy told her with a half smile.
She loved these tasks very much.
They were the only ones with a phone in this part of the neighborhood.
Their number was 150, and they willingly shared it with the neighbors.
At four years old, she served as the chief messenger, running between them with a sense of importance.
There was a warm and genuine closeness among these neighbors.
All living in identical houses, with similar gardens, each containing a guava tree they had once received for free.
It was a neighborhood of small white houses near the sea.
Only their house was both a home and a hotel, made from four such houses joined together.
Their garden was slightly larger, and Lucy ensured it bloomed all the time.
Only their house was pink, and that was its name, and only they had a phone.
In front of Illishka's house lay Danny's tricycle, her son, a year younger than her.
He was her friend.
Since none of the house doors were locked, she just pressed the handle and went inside.
The house smelled pleasantly of something baking in the oven.
Illishka faced her, a big bright smile appearing on her face.
She announced, the aunt from Haifa will call in 10 minutes.
Mom says you should come.
She turned around and was already running back home.
Kim ran with her, close to her legs.
He was her helper in important tasks.
Everyone in the neighborhood laughed when they saw the girl from the pink house, followed by a long red tail.
But a week ago, she ran to Erin's house, which was a bit further away.
Erin had no wife or children.
Lucy urged her, run and tell Aaron to come quickly.
And unlike other times, there was a concerned look on her face.
Aaron arrived, spoke on the phone, and became very pale.
Tears suddenly appeared in his eyes.
He slowly placed the receiver back, and then Lucy hugged him and told him she was very sorry.
There was nothing to be done.
That's how life is.
In the end, they finish, and we are left only with memories.
Aaron thanked her.
Come, sit, I'll make you a cup of tea.
It's not good to go back to an empty house now, wait a bit.
Only much later did he get up and return to his home.
She watched him go, and it seemed to her he walked more slowly, as if his legs were heavy and his body slightly hunched.
She approached Lucy quietly.
Is Aaron sad?
She asked.
Yes, dear, he is very sad because his only sister died.
She was very sick.
Do you know what it means to die?
Yes.
Like the bird that fell from the tree and you said it died and dad buried it in the dune out back.
It's when you can't fly anymore.
Right?
Lucy smiled a sad smile.
You are a very smart child.
That's exactly it, when you can't fly anymore, and mostly when you can't breathe anymore.
She picked her up in her arms and hugged her tight, and Lucy's face was as sad as Erin's.
Even then, when she was little, Lucy and Yosef treated her as if she were older.
Yet whenever Lucy spoke about her, she would say, the little one.
And she loved it.
She didn't mind being the little one at all.
Yosef called her kooky all those years.
Sometimes when he wanted to tease her, he'd call her kooky-mooky and she would laugh.
But beyond that, they treated her as an equal.
And now, as she'd grown a bit, they were.
Sure, she was already big and that there was almost no difference between the tasks and responsibilities they assigned her and those she took on herself.
Something changed in this house.
From the moment it became clear that Lucy's illness had returned.
Five years had passed since the first time and they already believed the story was behind them.
But then, suddenly, one morning, Lucy had a high fever, followed by a very low fever, and Dr. Horowitz, whom Yosef had called, immediately realized that the five years given to her had ended.
At first, Lucy tried to deny it, refusing treatments and hospitalization, until she realized there was no choice.

In this pink hotel, there were endless tasks to perform, and she, the little one, Kukimuki, devoted herself in the mornings before school and immediately after to helping her father and the workers as much as she could.
Her father watched her from the side with a look of admiration and sadness.
He understood that the little one was forced to grow up all at once, that it wouldn't be long before she'd have to grow up completely.
But once he saw that she managed her tasks, he seemed to wish to forget her age and was glad to lift some of the burdens from his shoulders.
Sometimes, in her heart, she wanted to be a little more little, like all her friends who were busy with the silly things of adolescence.
with boys, clothes, fun chats, and nonsense.
But even before, it didn't really interest her.
She was always immersed in the books she read, the music she listened to and played, and a few friends she held closer to her heart than others.
Some years earlier, after elementary school, her teacher Rachel visited the pink house and told Lucy that her little one had read almost all the books in the library she was responsible for.
I've never seen anything like it.
How much she loves to read."
But she also writes beautiful essays.
Once, she forgot to prepare her homework in composition, and when asked to read what she'd written, she lifted her blank notebook, pretending to read, and read a lovely story she made up on the spot.
And her language is beautiful, Rachel said to her mother.
And Lucy was so proud of her, and she was so happy.
Later, in high school, when she had to prepare homework in mathematics, which she neither liked nor understood, she'd ask Leon, a new immigrant who knew math brilliantly.
to do it for her.
In return she promised to write compositions for him because he still struggled with Hebrew, a kind of barter.
It worked beautifully until Chani, the math teacher, caught on and laughed heartily.
It's a genius idea, kudos for thinking of it, but unfortunately it won't work during exams.
not for you, and not for him.
And they all laughed together, without anger.
And suddenly, a bit of the small childhood things were disappearing.
And in the mornings, she would rise early to set the tables for breakfast.
And the moment school ended, she'd rush back home, not lingering to chat with friends.
They ask her, where are you running to?
and she'd smile in embarrassment, not wanting to reveal, inventing a different excuse each time.
By the end of the days, she was a bit tired.
She didn't fully understand what her mother's illness meant.
She was sure that like the last time, they'd give her some medicine and it would pass.
She suppressed it and also didn't receive too much information, for which she was still probably too young.
Two or three months passed, Lucy's condition worsened, and she was hospitalized.
Then, they began taking shifts, traveling to Tel Aviv's Asuda Hospital, once her, once her father.
Every time she went to her, she'd find her in a worse state.
Pale, very thin, barely smiling at her.
Once, Lucy even asked her not to come anymore.
But why, mom?
Leora asked insistently, I don't want you to remember me like this.
I want you to remember me as I was.
Lucy answered her with a serious, painful and frustrated expression.
She didn't know what to say to her.
So she promised she'd always remember her as beautiful and wonderful as she was.
You'll see it will pass.
She tried to comfort her, still not knowing what her mother fully understood.
But now after Lucy passed away, suddenly the days were emptied of the constant activity around her.
and Leora began to wonder what she was supposed to do now.
All her friends still went every morning to high school to the seventh grade while she was confined at home in their hotel with her father who also seemed to find no rest.
Danny who called her Annabelle Lee asked her one day why she decided to stop her studies and not start seventh grade.
She told him that during one of the doctor's visits to the hospital
She was asked to step out into the corridor and stood in the corner.
When they came out, the professor and two other doctors there didn't notice her.
And the professor spoke quietly and sadly, explaining to them that nothing was working anymore.
She had metastases in the lymph nodes and esophagus.
She had difficulty swallowing, and she wouldn't last much longer, maybe two months, maybe not even that.
He asked them to ease her suffering as much as possible because she was in great pain.
He spoke with sadness.
During the months of treating her, he had developed affection and respect for her.
And he also understood she was no ordinary woman.
He respected her wisdom and sharp sense of humor and saw before him a true lady whose remnants of beauty were still apparent, fading away.
And she heard it all, heard, and was shaken, but said nothing.
This happened in mid-August.
Two weeks later, school year was supposed to start.
But in the evening, as she returned exhausted by bus from Tel Aviv and sat to have a cup of coffee with Josef.
The decision was already made within her.
She looked deeply into his eyes and said to him, Daddy, I can always study.
In two months, I won't have a mom and I want to stay with her.

He returned a sad gaze, but didn't argue, didn't ask how she knew, didn't ask how she felt, understood her completely because to him, the little one was completely big, big enough to make such a decision, big enough to understand the end of life.
Big enough to understand that sometimes time is a precious thing that must be filled with matters of the heart because they won't return.
They are finished.
She was both little and big.
